sections.challenge: The manual process of entering Bill of Materials (BOM) data from PDFs and images into the SQL database was extremely time-consuming and prone to human error. A single document took an average of 8 minutes (5-6 minutes for data entry and 1-2 minutes for verification), limiting productivity to only 6-7 documents per hour.
sections.solution:
We designed and implemented an AI-powered OCR system to automate the data extraction process. The solution leverages a multi-stage pipeline that includes:

The system consists of three main components:


1. **Table Detection**

   


- Uses object detection model
   


- Identifies and isolates table structures
   


- Detects key data fields and layouts


  - Processes multiple table formats


2. **Data Extraction**


   - Utilizes **PaddleOCR** for text recognition


   - Employs **PaddleStructure** for structural analysis


  - Uses **Docling PDF Extractor** for PDF parsing


   - Handles both textual and structured data


3. **Data Validation**


  - Powered by **Qwen2.5-VL-32B** model


   - Validates extracted data accuracy


   - Reconstructs complete tables


   - Ensures data consistency
sections.impact: This automated pipeline significantly reduced the time required for data processing and increased overall productivity. The time per document was cut down to just 1-2 minutes, boosting the workload from 6-7 PDFs per hour to 15 PDFs per hour. In the future, we aim to further improve the pipeline's accuracy to enable direct data integration into the database.

metrics.title: Time Reduction
metrics.description: Reduced time per document from 8 to 2 minutes

metrics.title: Productivity Increase
metrics.description: Boosted productivity from 6 to 15 PDFs per hour

metrics.title: Error Reduction
metrics.description: Minimized human error in data entry
